item.title: Solving linear systems
item.description: How to solve Ax=b? One of the most important computational tasks in NLA. Solving triangular systems Â§ Solve triangular system. Draw system and solution process.

item.title: Dot product
item.description: Notation: xTy=x1â€‹y1â€‹+â‹¯+xnâ€‹ynâ€‹ Two vectors x and y are orthogonal if xTy=0. For a subspace S, we can define SâŠ¥ as the subspace of vectors y such that: SâŠ¥={yâˆ£âˆ€xâˆˆS,xTy=0} We have: dim(S)+dim(SâŠ¥)=n.

item.title: Singular value decomposition
item.description: One of the most important matrix decomposition in data science and machine learning. Eigenvalues are great for understanding An. Does it grow? Does it shrink? How can it be easily modeled? But it says nothing about the size of Ax.

item.title: Bootcamp
item.description: More during recitation + read the chapter in textbook for full background Vectors and matrices Introduce notations Subspace and linear independence Core concept in linear algebra Important when solving linear systems Dot product Shows up in many places.

item.title: Invertible matrix
item.description: A matrix A is invertible if and only if there is a matrix B such that AB=BA=I We denote: B=Aâˆ’1. A matrix that is not invertible is said to be singular.

item.title: Unitarily diagonalizable matrices
item.description: A matrix AâˆˆCnÃ—n is unitarily diagonalizable if there is a unitary matrix Q and a diagonal matrix Î› so that A=QÎ›QH Definition: A is normal if and only if AHA=AAH.

item.title: Vector norms
item.description: Key tool for proofs and formal derivations Essential to describe and understand properties of objects in LA Used to convert a vector to a single scalar number, its â€œsize.

item.title: Subspace and linear independence
item.description: Vector subspace Â§ Vector space: a set of elements that can be added together and multiplied by scalars (for this class, in R or C). Vectors and matrices Example: Rn.

item.title: Matrix-vector and matrix-matrix product
item.description: Vectors and matrices, Dot product A matrix can be defined as a linear map from Rnâ†’Rm. This is the operator view of a matrix: A:xâ†’Ax. Algebraically, we write y=Ax with yiâ€‹=j=1âˆ‘nâ€‹aijâ€‹xjâ€‹ Using the operator interpretation, we can define the product of two matrices C=AB as the result of composing A with B: Cx=(AB)x=A(Bx) This works when B:Rnâ†’Rp and A:Rpâ†’Rm.

item.title: Hermitian and symmetric matrices
item.description: The most important example of unitarily diagonalizable matrices. Complex Hermitian: A=AH. Then: A=QÎ›QH and Î› real. Real symmetric: A=AT. Then A=QÎ›QT and Î› and Q are real.
